Advanced Vocabulary - Page 4

Advanced

Advanced Vocabulary - Page 4

Continue mastering advanced vocabulary with these sophisticated terms used in academic discourse, literature, and professional communication.

Navigation

This is page 4 of 12. Use the navigation below to explore all vocabulary pages.

Word List

Colloquial

/kəˈloʊkwiəl/

adjective

Used in ordinary or familiar conversation; not formal or literary.

"The professor used colloquial expressions to make her lecture more accessible."

Synonyms: informal, conversational, vernacular

Category: Language

Complacent

/kəmˈpleɪsənt/

adjective

Showing smug or uncritical satisfaction with oneself or one's achievements.

"Success made him complacent, and he stopped striving for improvement."

Synonyms: self-satisfied, smug, content

Category: Attitude

Connoisseur

/ˌkɑːnəˈsɜːr/

noun

An expert judge in matters of taste.

"As a wine connoisseur, she could identify the vintage and region by taste alone."

Synonyms: expert, aficionado, specialist

Category: Expertise

Contentious

/kənˈtenʃəs/

adjective

Causing or likely to cause an argument; controversial.

"The contentious issue divided the committee into opposing factions."

Synonyms: controversial, disputed, argumentative

Category: Conflict

Cosmopolitan

/ˌkɑːzməˈpɑːlɪtən/

adjective

Familiar with and at ease in many different countries and cultures.

"Her cosmopolitan outlook came from years of international travel."

Synonyms: worldly, sophisticated, international

Category: Culture

Credulity

/krəˈduləti/

noun

A tendency to be too ready to believe that something is real or true.

"His credulity made him an easy target for scam artists."

Synonyms: gullibility, naivety, trustfulness

Category: Judgment

Cursory

/ˈkɜːrsəri/

adjective

Hasty and therefore not thorough or detailed.

"A cursory examination revealed several obvious errors."

Synonyms: superficial, brief, perfunctory

Category: Thoroughness

Cynical

/ˈsɪnɪkəl/

adjective

Believing that people are motivated purely by self-interest; distrustful of human sincerity.

"His cynical view of politics prevented him from voting."

Synonyms: skeptical, pessimistic, distrustful

Category: Perspective

Debacle

/dɪˈbɑːkəl/

noun

A sudden and ignominious failure; a fiasco.

"The product launch turned into a complete debacle."

Synonyms: disaster, fiasco, catastrophe

Category: Failure

Deference

/ˈdefərəns/

noun

Humble submission and respect.

"She showed appropriate deference to her mentor's expertise."

Synonyms: respect, reverence, submission

Category: Respect

Deleterious

/ˌdeləˈtɪriəs/

adjective

Causing harm or damage.

"The deleterious effects of pollution on marine life are well documented."

Synonyms: harmful, damaging, detrimental

Category: Harm

Demagogue

/ˈdeməɡɑːɡ/

noun

A political leader who seeks support by appealing to popular desires and prejudices.

"The demagogue used inflammatory rhetoric to gain followers."

Synonyms: rabble-rouser, agitator, populist

Category: Politics
